Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide support for participants, especially women and mathematicians from other under-represented groups, graduate students, postdocs, and young faculty, to the Maryland Dynamics Conference. This is a long-standing series of conferences that are held each spring at the University of Maryland at College Park. The award will fund the 2013, 2014 and 2015 iterations of this conference.

The semi-annual Maryland Dynamics Conference is a spring workshop/conference. This workshop first met at Penn State in 1991. It has hosted by Maryland each spring and by Penn State each fall since 1992. The workshop is devoted to recent progress in dynamical systems and related fields. It have been regularly attracting leading experts in the field. Such outstanding mathematicians as Fefferman, Furstenberg, Lindenstrauss. Margulis, Mather, Ornstein, Sinai, Yoccoz took part in the past conferences.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award provided primary support for the Spring meetings of the Workshop on Dynamical Systems and Related topics at the University of Maryland, held in 2013-2015. Maryland workshop is one of two annual meetings cosponsored by the dynamics groups at the University of Maryland and Penn State, the other being held in the Fall at Penn State. The webpage  for the conference, including the schedules of the talks can be found at

http://dynamics.math.umd.edu/conferences/


Dynamics is a very broad discipline; talks at these meetings generally include a wide range of topics. 2013 meeting was organized by Marcel Guardia and Vadim Kaloshin, 2014 meeting was organized by Joe Auslander, Giovanni Forni and Kelly Yancey, 2015 meeting was organized by Dmitry Dolgopyat and Yuri Lima.

Part of the intellectual merit of this comes through the communication of ideas, both through formal talks and informal interaction, especially in interdisciplinary contacts. Less direct but very important for intellectual outcomes is the formation and strengthing of the personal relationships which are fundamental for collaboration and consultation. The broader impact of this includes the integration of younger people into the dynamics research community. Each meeting included a significant portion (at least 1/3 and often higher) of speakers who were at the graduate student, postdoctoral or pretenure stage of their careers (some of these talks were given in half hour double sessions).  The conference speakers were primarily affiliated to American institutions, but also came from universities in Canada, Chile, Finland, France, India and Israel; participants likewise were primarily from American instutitions, but also included representatives of several countries.
